div.head: To my worthiest friend Master W. C. on his Booke, La Dance Machabre.
div.l: FRiend, thou do'st ill to ranke me in this place,
Though I shall honor thee in my disgrace.
For as choice dainties, after grosser food,
Taste better farre, then other wayes they would:
So men by reading this harsh verse of mine,
Shall rellish better these sweet straines of thine.
What boot these lines alasse? When euery one
May read they prayses written in thine owne.
Such needlesse things may make weake people deeme,
Thy Booke wants sureties to beget esteeme.
Here hath thy sad Muse, like a dying Swan,
Sung a sweet storie, of the death of man.
O, may shee liue, that glad-deceiued we,
May heare her often sing such melodie.
